tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use for this neck pain

we are assuming a neck pain caused by muscle strain from holding the neck too long in a particular position like sleeping or falling asleep on the sofa. This could be a sprain in the upper back or neck muscles.

If you think it is due to muscle tightness, seek urgent care. No muscle relaxants over-the-counter.

With this in mind, see what we recommend to use over-the-counter.

collapsable.title: NSAIDs click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Non-Steroidal Antiinflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) will help with the inflammation and pain. Take these as soon as possible for maximum effect.

Ibuprofen and naproxen are good examples.

If it just happened, combine this with ice/cold compress for the first 2 days while the inflammation is still developing.

collapsable.title: Pain Patch / Cream click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Massaging a pain relief cream or applying the patch should provide relief for a few hours. 4 hours on the average.

Prefer the cream if you can handle the smell. If using the patch, massage the area before applying the patch.

You can compare pain relief patches or creams using our comparison tool.

collapsable.title: Worth Doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Apply ice for the first 2 to 3 days, then apply heat or warm compress thereafter.

2. Use a soft neck collar. Be sure to take it off from time to time to prevent muscle weakness and do not use for more than 4 or 5 days.

3. Acupuncture or chiropractor if you can afford it.

4. Massage

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/03/2016

tabs.header: Know this about the safe and effective use of this recommendation.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

tabs.header:
What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over-the-counter for chest congestion relief.

We are assuming this chest congestion is a result of mucus accumulating in the airways. Remedies for a chest congestion over-the-counter are tailored towards thinning or enhancing the flow of mucus.

With this in mind, see what we recommend below.

collapsable.title: Expectorant click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Guaifenesin. This is the most common expectorant over-the-counter. It is taken to help in bringing up mucus (expectorate) from the respiratory tract. It reduces the viscosity of mucus in the airways which increase the ability of the body to keep it moving, improving the coughing reflex mechanism making you cough it up. 

Regular or 12 hr. Which should you take?

We recommend the 12-hour formulation if cost is not a factor for you. These are timed release not that they are stronger. Guaifenesin will need to be released gradually and continuously to loosen the thick dried up mucus causing this chest congestion.

To make this effective, you must keep drinking water. Full glass at a time, not tiny sips. Err on the side of too much water.

collapsable.title: Do These click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Drink a lot of water. Add lemon.

2. Steam therapy. For 20 minutes at a time.

3. Chest rub. Vicks vapor rub is a good example. Sit in a steamy shower with it.

4. Manuka honey.

5. Hot showers, bath.

6. Suck on cough drops for the purpose of moisturizing the respiratory tract.

7. If you are taking an antihistamine, stop for now. It makes the mucus thicker and you want to loosen it. Do the saline rinse instead if you have a runny nose.

8. Garlic, ginger, if you have any.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/03/2016

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over-the-counter for this back pain.

We will take a look at what is available over-the-counter for acute lower back pain. If it is chronic (lasting more than 3 months), you must be seeing a doctor for this.

Now, let's see what is recommended to do over-the-counter.

collapsable.title: Pain Pills click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
NSAIDS (Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs)

Ibuprofen or naproxen will be a good choice especially if the back pain is within 48 hours. At this stage inflammation is developing and an anti-inflammatory drug will be a good choice.

Take acetaminophen if you can't tolerate NSAIDS. But make sure you combine a pain patch or cream with it.

Other NSAIDs used for back pain include salicylates. An example is Magnesium salicylate. The active ingredient in Doan's. Aspirin is another example.

Combination  pills usually include NSAIDS with Caffeine. These are better for headaches.

collapsable.title: Pain Patches / Creams click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These will provide relief for about 4 hours at a time. Be sure to compare these using our comparison tool. 

Most contain Methyl Salicylate, an NSAID, and /or Menthol and/or Camphor at various percentages.

collapsable.title: TENS Therapy click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) therapy uses a low-voltage electric current from electrodes placed on the skin to stimulate the nerves for pain relief.

Getting the right stimulation intensity is critical for pain relief.

These are thought to prevent pain impulses from reaching the brain and stimulating the body to produce the natural painkiller called endorphins.

Should you invest in this? Well, they are expensive. Know that they block pain perception. It won't work on inflammation or reduce any swelling nor will it heal the affected area. So you will still need to combine an NSAID for effectiveness. 

It is good to have at home however for most types of pain.

collapsable.title: Cold / Warm Compress click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Ice

Use this for the first 2 to 3 days of the onset of back pain. At this point, inflammation is going on and it need to be suppressed as much as possible.

Heat

Use heat to relax the muscle

collapsable.title: Worth Doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Try lying in a curled-up position with a pillow between your legs while sleeping.

2. No bed rest.  Reduce activity during the first 2 days and gradually get back to your usual activities.  ​

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/03/2016

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what to use over the counter for this.

This will assume you are combining lifestyle and dietary changes with over-the-counter measures to tackle this heartburn issue if it is an existing problem.

Over-the-counter medications to treat heartburn are generally classified into 3 categories listed below.

You will use information about these 3 categories to choose what will work best for you.

Let's figure this out.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose your symptoms from the list below and see what is recommended.
fieldset: Burning pain. Feels like food is trying to come back into the throat.
I need something for immediate relief.
I have used omeprazole or other PPIs for 2 weeks or more recently.
Feels like food is stuck in the throat when I swallow.
Stool is black like tar or maroon colored.
Did some sit-ups. Now my chest is feeling this burning sensation.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

Sorry, we must have left some things out. Please choose what you think closely resembles what you are experiencing and see what is recommended.
mode.2: Something to prevent?
mode.3: Selection require an antacid.
mode.4: Selection require an antigas medication.
mode.5: Selection require a h2 blocker type of medication.
mode.6: Selection require a PPI group of medications.
mode.7: Selection require seeking urgent care.
mode.8: Symptoms require an antacid and an antigas combination.
mode.9: Symptoms require an antacid and a h2 blocker class of medications.
mode.10: Symptoms require an antacid and a PPI group of medications.
mode.11: Symptoms require an antacid and for you to see a doctor
mode.12: Symptoms require an antigas and a h2 blocker class of medications
mode.13: Symptoms require an antigas and a PPI group of medications
mode.14: Symptoms require an antigas and for you to see a doctor.
mode.15: Symptoms require a h2 blocker type acid reducer and a PPI group of medications
mode.16: Symptoms require a h2 blocker type acid reducer and for you to see a doctor.
mode.17: Symptoms require a PPI type of acid reducer and for you to see a doctor
mode.18: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas or combination and a h2 blocker class of medications.
mode.19: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas or combination and a PPI group of acid reducers.
mode.20: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas and you have to seek urgent care.
mode.21: Symptoms require an antacid, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and or a PPI group of medications.
mode.22: Symptoms require an antacid, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.23: Symptoms require an antacid, a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.24: Symptoms require an antigas, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and or a PPI group of medications.
mode.25: Symptoms require an antigas, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.26: Symptoms require an antigas, a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.27: Symptoms require a h2 blocker type of acid reducer, and or a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.28: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and or a PPI group of medications.
mode.29: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas, a h2 blocker type acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.30: Symptoms require an antacid, antigas or combination, a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.31: Symptoms require an antacid, a h2 blocker type acid reducer, or a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.32: Symptoms require an antigas, a h2 blocker type acid reducer, a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care
mode.33: Symptoms require an antacid, an antigas or combination, a h2 blocker type acid reducer, and or a PPI type of acid reducer and you have to seek urgent care.
mode.50: Oops!, You told me nothing

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 02/17/2016

collapsable.title: Antacids click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Antacids contain alkaline ions (bicarbonate, carbonate or hydroxide) and counterions (Calcium, Magnesium, Sodium, Aluminum) that help to neutralise stomach acids. You should start getting relief in about 30 mins.

The liquid formulation work faster. But the tablets are better for taking along because you may have to take this frequently until you get relief.

Be sure to compare OTC antacids using our comparison tool. For instance some you shouldn't take if you have diarrhea and some if you have constipation.

collapsable.title: H2 blockers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These reduce acid production in the stomach by blocking the H2 receptors in the stomach. They are not as effective as Proton pump inhibitors but are a good alternative if cost is a problem.

Know that these are used to suppress stomach acid. Don't expect them to work right away if you already have heartburn. They are much better for prevention. If you already have this heartburn, you will have to include an antacid to neutralize the acid already present for fast relief and then use this to prevent further acid production.

Cimetidine, Famotidine, Ranitidine, and nizatidine are examples.

collapsable.title: Antigas click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Simethicone is the main ingredient that dissolves the gas in cases of bloating.

This is an anti-foaming agent that combines tiny air bubbles in the stomach into a bigger one that you can then belch out or pass as gas.

You would use this if you are experiencing bloating along with a heartburn. Some heartburn medications combine this with antacids. This combination is usually preferred.

collapsable.title: Proton Pump Inhibitors click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Omeprazole, Lansoprazole, Esomeprazole. These are used to suppress acid production in the stomach.

The FDA recommends not more than three 14-day treatment courses to be used in one year. This should be sufficient for you. By that I mean, do it 14 days at a time and if you add good dietary habits and other lifestyle changes, you should not need it for more than 3 times in one year.

This is how these drugs work. They irreversibly inhibit the pump that produces acid in the stomach called proton pump. They can knock out up to 99% of these pumps irreversibly which means they will never come back. A 14-day treatment should make this happen. But the stomach will form new pumps to replace the ones that were knocked out which will gradually take a while (average 2 to 3 months) to reach the levels that were causing heartburn before. So if you add good dietary and lifestyle changes to your treatment plan, you should not have to be taking these medications every day just for heartburn relief.

Which should you choose? Well, you will have to use the comparison feature of this app to help you with that.

collapsable.title: Lifestyle changes click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.

collapsable.title: Antacid click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will use this to neutralize the stomach acid already present. This should give you relief within the next 30 mins.

Use the comparison feature of this app to choose a good one that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Antigas click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This contains simethicone the ingredient that dissolves the gas in the stomach.

You will take this if you are feeling bloated. Expect some belching. When this happens, you should start feeling better.

collapsable.title: H2 Blocker click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will want to take this to reduce the production of stomach acid.

Know that it reduces the production of the acid and it will take a few days to kick in. So you may need to combine this with an antacid to neutralise the acid that is already present in the stomach.

Compare H2 blockers using the comparison feature of this app to see which will work best for you.

Just a reminder, you should take this OR a proton pump inhibitor and not both at the same time.

collapsable.title: PPI(Proton pump inhibitors) click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will need this to suppress acid production in the stomach. Know that it takes a while to kick in. If you also need something for immediate relief, add an antacid to neutralize the acid that is currently present in the stomach while this will prevent more from being formed. After a couple of days, you can then stop taking the antacid and continue with a proton pump inhibitor.

Be sure to compare the different types using the comparison table of this app to know which to choose between omeprazole, pantoprazole, esomeprazole.

collapsable.title: Seek Urgent Care click to expand contents
collapsable.content: You will have to see a healthcare provider on this one. Over-the-counter or self-care is not going to take care of this. Don't waste your time and money. It will get worse.

collapsable.title: Combination Products click to expand contents
Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You will have to work on these:

  • Carbonated drinks
  • Alcohol
  • Coffee
  • Caffeinated energy drinks
  • Chocolate, mints or peppermints
  • Citrus fruits
  • Fatty or spicy foods
  • Tomato products
  • Smoking
  • Taking ibuprofen, naproxen or aspirin

Take these seriously. You may want to make a list and place it on the refrigerator as a reminder.
